results.title: Germany Will Offer Vaccine Booster Shots Starting in September
results.abstract: In rich countries, the momentum is growing for giving additional doses to the fully vaccinated, though many experts say the focus should be on getting first doses to people around the world.

results.title: Haitians Investigating President’s Death, Under Threat, Go Into Hiding
results.abstract: The officials, two court clerks and an investigative judge who collected evidence in President Jovenel Moïse’s assassination, are now in hiding.

results.abstract: As Venice’s ban on cruise ships took effect this weekend, some tourists were surprised to be docked hours away from the city’s famous sights.

results.title: Queen Guitarist’s Flooded London Basement Foretells a Climate Under Pressure
results.abstract: After a heat wave and two Southeast Asia-style rainstorms that flooded the capital’s streets, subways and Brian May’s cellar, it seems timely to ask if the city is prepared to deal with wild weather.

multimedia.caption: Streets in Richmond, a neighborhood of London, in May, when the Thames River breached its banks.

results.title: Belarusian Sprinter Who Feared for Her Safety Is Offered Asylum in Poland
results.abstract: Kristina Timanovskaya sought help at a Tokyo airport as her country tried to forcibly send her home from the Olympics.
results.byline: By Motoko Rich and Tariq Panja

results.title: Where a Vast Global Vaccination Program Went Wrong
results.abstract: After months of struggle, the U.N.-backed Covax alliance will soon have many more doses, promising relief for vaccine shortages in poorer countries. But it faces a deepening crisis: difficulties getting shots into arms as the Delta variant spreads.
results.byline: By Benjamin Mueller and Rebecca Robbins

multimedia.caption: Carrying a box of vaccines this spring in Goma, in the Democratic Republic of Congo. The country received 1.7 million AstraZeneca doses through Covax in March, but distribution is another challenge.

results.title: With #MeToo Case, China Takes a Swipe at Celebrity Obsession
results.abstract: The detention of Kris Wu, a popular Canadian singer, has been hailed as a rare victory for the movement. But Beijing, wary of social activism, has cast it as a warning to celebrities.
results.byline: By Amy Qin and Elsie Chen

multimedia.caption: The performer Kris Wu at a movie premiere in Los Angeles in 2017. He has become perhaps the most prominent figure in China to be detained over #MeToo allegations.
The performer Kris Wu at a movie premiere in Los Angeles in 2017. He has become perhaps the most prominent figure in China to be detained over #MeToo allegations.

results.title: Top Myanmar General Says Military Rule Will Continue Into 2023
results.abstract: Six months after seizing power, the junta’s leader on Sunday extended a state of emergency for two more years. Protesters said they would persevere.
des_facet: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

multimedia.caption: A rally on Thursday in Yangon, Myanmar, against military rule. People across the country have been gathering for brief protests, then dispersing before the security forces can crack down.
A rally on Thursday in Yangon, Myanmar, against military rule. People across the country have been gathering for brief protests, then dispersing before the security forces can crack down.

results.title: Tunisia’s President Holds Forth on Freedoms After Seizing Power
results.abstract: “‘Why do you think that, at 67, I would start a career as a dictator?’” President Kais Saied said in a meeting with The New York Times, quoting Charles de Gaulle. He vowed to preserve hard-fought rights.

multimedia.caption: President Kais Saied of Tunisia, center, leading a security meeting with members of the army and police forces last week in Tunis.

results.title: Russia Scoffs at Olympic Ban: ‘Let Them Listen to Classical Music’
results.abstract: Sports fans and officials in the country have no trouble seeing through the thin fiction of a doping-related ban on their national symbols at the Tokyo Olympics.

multimedia.caption: Outside the Luzhniki Stadium in Moscow on Saturday. With humor and pride, Russians are gloating over their athletes’ many medals this summer despite a prohibition on their nation’s symbols at the Tokyo Games.

results.title: Even the Pope Has Prayed to Venezuela’s Beloved ‘Doctor of the Poor’
results.abstract: In a deeply polarized country, suffering an extreme health crisis, one of the few uniting beliefs is the admiration across the political spectrum for a doctor recently beatified by the Vatican.
results.byline: By Meridith Kohut and Isayen Herrera

multimedia.caption: Devotees carrying an image of Dr. José Gregorio Hernández during a procession through the streets of Isnotú, the small town in Venezuela where he was born in 1864.

results.title: Lynn C. Franklin, Literary Agent and Memoirist on Adoption, Dies at 74
results.abstract: She represented Desmond Tutu and Deepak Chopra, but the book closest to her was the one she wrote about giving up her baby and then reuniting with him.

results.title: Riots Shatter Veneer of Coexistence in Israel’s Mixed Towns

results.title: With Undersea Robots, an Air Force Navigator Lost Since 1967 Is Found
results.abstract: A recovery mission off Vietnam’s coast showed how advances in technology have given new reach to the Pentagon’s search for American war dead.
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces

multimedia.caption: Preparing to launch one of three robotic vehicles to survey the seafloor off Vietnam in February 2020. The search led to the recovery of an Air Force navigator’s remains.

results.title: Gov. Greg Abbott bars mandates for vaccinations and masks in Texas.
results.abstract: The state’s daily average of cases has risen more than 200 percent over the past 14 days and hospitalizations are surging, but an executive order ensures that masking and vaccinations remain voluntary.
